entry.title: surviving takin
entry.msg:
64-bit vs. 2n-bit

In terms of programming, 32-bit is slowly shifting to 64-bit and with the technology we currently have, so why wouldn't there be innovations for 128-bit, 256-bit, etc programming? Would that increase speed & performance?

entry.title: loose llama
entry.msg:
Signed 64 bit numbers are HUGE and will probably be enough for quite some time.  For example, Linux has been using a 32 bit Epoch time clock.  This is the number of seconds since 1/1/1970.  Unfortunately, this 32 bit clock will overflow in 2038 (Links to an external site.).  Of course, everything will switch over to 64 bit Epoch time to prevent catastrophic breakdown (though nuclear warhead launchers will likely still have old 32 bit clocks but nothing to worry about).  So how long until the 64 bit timestamp wraps around and forces us to use 128 bit timestamps?   Approximately 292 billion years from now.  This is just one example of how large 64 bit values really are.

Obviously strings and BLOBs can be trillions of bytes so being able to manipulate them quickly is always useful.  But as far numeric integer values, 64 bits is more than enough for typical purposes.  Scientific computing is another issue altogether and there are cases were extremely high precision floating point numbers are very useful.  But for gaming, internet and accounting?  64 bit will be useful for a very long time.

entry.title: spatial snipe
entry.msg: Unless clock speed increases, speed of the processor cannot be increased as per my understanding and readings.  Any processor above 64 bit processor is not yet commercially available. As explained in other replies to your post, currently there is plenty of room till we catchup to the limitations of 64 bit processor, but in my opinion we may soon see 128 bit processor as well.  I may think like multiple cores on a processor, CPU may perform multiple partitions of bits and create parallelism, which I am not entirely sure if that is possible.

entry.title: faithful firefly
entry.msg:
There are totally innovations for such programming! Intel's AVX-512 works with 512-bit numbers on a 64 bit processor. Intel claims that this can help to increase throughput in such tasks as machine learning. Unfortunately, in many tasks that use floating point numbers increasing the precision beyond 64 bits is not particularly useful. Consider the fact that the some of the most precise physical measurements ever performed had an accuracy within a few parts in 10^13 (https://physics.stackexchange.com/questions/497087/what-is-the-most-precise-physical-measurement-ever-performed), while 2^512 is in the ballpark is of 10^514! Furthermore, with more bits comes with slowdowns in processing. Using AVX-512 comes with a 25 percent slowdown in clock speed. 64 bits is a good compromise for representing many physical quantities such as time, but not so processor intensive that it harms performance.

Also note that high bit counts mean that you are typically using high-precision floating point numbers, as there aren't many tasks that require calculating integers that large. Nowadays, intensive floating point operations are generally left to the GPU.

entry.title: genuine gopher
entry.msg:
Reserved words

Why can't reserved words be used as identifies?

entry.title: surviving takin
entry.msg: For example in C++, if you name an integer variable "string" the compiler wouldn't be able to properly differentiate the actual function of a string, used to define multiple characters, and it being a variable name, therefore string is a reserved word. The same applies to assembly programming.

entry.title: Cole Gannon
entry.msg: string is not a reserved word in C or C++. You can do int string = 1 just fine. A good example of a reserved word in C++ would be if. As for the reason why reserved words exist in any language, that's just how the language works. The language uses those reserved words for it's own purposes. They're not user changable.

entry.title: driving deer
entry.msg: Adding on to what Cole said, I think that the reserved words are simply a part of the language's syntax. I think that another good example in C++ specifically, is doing something like int int = 0;. It simply doesn't make sense to create an int variable named int since int is already necessary for specifying the variable type. If you then tried to print out the variable by doing something like cout << int;, then it would not make any sense.

entry.title: passive owl
entry.msg:
The character 'h' behind the code.

Example: str1 BYTE "Enter name: ",0Dh,0Ah 

How can I understand the "h" that always behind the code "0D" & "0A"?

entry.title: loose llama
entry.msg: The "h" suffix indicates that the value is hexadecimal.  For example in C/C++ you would use 0x1234 for hex, but in MASM you would use 1234h.  If your hex values starts with an alpha character, then you need to prefix the value with a zero.  So for example in C/C++ you could write 0xABCD, but MASM requires 0ABCDh.  MASM would assume that ABCDh must be a constant, label or variable name.

MOV Mnemonic

The book describes the MOV mnemonic, which moves a value from one register to another. For example, "MOV eax, ebx" would move the value in the ebx register to eax. Does this overwrite eax completely, or is the value that was previously in eax get stored somewhere in memory?

entry.title: supposed swordtail

entry.title: financial fowl
entry.msg: So for any x86 register, there is a term called "scratch" that allows any function to overwrite another and can use it for anything, no questions asked. In this case, the value in the ebx register completely overwrites the eax register and there is no trace of the former value in eax.

entry.title: electoral dragon
entry.msg:
Integer Literals

I had a question on the "encoded real"  (r) radix. Is this the only way to store floats/numbers with a decimal point in assembly? And why is it classified as an integer literal if it is used to describe floats?

Thanks!

entry.title: entitled earwig
entry.msg: The radix refers to the base of the number, such as hexadecimal (base 16), binary (base 2), etc. For example, typing in h at the end of the number (as the radix), lets you type in hexadecimal numbers. The radix is not necessarily used to describe floats, but to specify the base of the integer literal. Floats are described using real number literals, not integer literals.

entry.title: conscious cattle
entry.msg:
Ok so the first instruction deals with a word size of 3 bytes referring to '66 8B C3' so it takes up 3 bytes of space starting from byte address 00000000.

Now the second instruction nop is starting from byte address 00000003 and inputs the byte '90' to take up the 1 byte of space. It acts essentially as a buffer and then leaves us at byte address 00000004.

This essentially aligns the address so that the processor will be able to access memory more quickly since the next instruction will begin at an address that is a multiple of 4.

Hope that explains it.
